articles.headline: U.S. Court Is Now Guiding Fewer Nations
articles.snippet: A diminishing number of foreign courts seem to pay attention to the writings of the Supreme Court justices.
articles.abstract: A diminishing number of foreign courts seem to pay attention to the writings of the Supreme Court justices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Judges around the world have long looked to the decisions of the United States Supreme Court for guidance, citing and often following them in hundreds of their own rulings since the Second World War.

articles.headline: Abroad, Bailout Is Seen as a Free Market Detour
articles.snippet: In rescuing A.I.G., Washington has likely undercut future efforts to promote free market policies abroad.
articles.abstract: In rescuing A.I.G., Washington has likely undercut future efforts to promote free market policies abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Is the United States no longer the global beacon of unfettered, free-market capitalism?

articles.headline: A New Zune for Serious Music Fans
articles.snippet: Apple introduces new iPods and Microsoft offers a Zune with more bells and whistles.
articles.abstract: Apple introduces new iPods and Microsoft offers a Zune with more bells and whistles.
articles.lead_paragraph: This might sound kind of weird, but here it is: the iPod and the Zune aren’t rivals anymore.

articles.headline: McCain Seen as Less Likely to Bring Change, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain is widely viewed as a “typical Republican” who would continue or expand President Bush’s policies.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain is widely viewed as a “typical Republican” who would continue or expand President Bush’s policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Despite an intense effort to distance himself from the way his party has done business in Washington, Senator John McCain is seen by voters as far less likely to bring change to Washington than Senator Barack Obama. He is widely viewed as a “typical Republican” who would continue or expand President Bush’s policies, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Robin Toner and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Asia Rethinks American Investments Amid Market Upheaval
articles.snippet: Many investors in Asia are questioning the wisdom of being invested in the U.S. to the tune of trillions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Many investors in Asia are questioning the wisdom of being invested in the U.S. to the tune of trillions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Tremors from Wall Street are rattling Asian confidence, leading many investors to question the wisdom of being invested in the United States to the tune of trillions of dollars.

articles.headline: Federal Aid to Detroit Seems Likely
articles.snippet: Support seemed to be growing quickly on Capitol Hill for $25 billion in loan guarantees to assist the auto industry.
articles.abstract: Support seemed to be growing quickly on Capitol Hill for $25 billion in loan guarantees to assist the auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After a series of government interventions in the private markets, one seemingly more astonishing than the next, lawmakers found themselves confronted on Wednesday with the question of when and where to draw the line on future aid.

articles.headline: As Fears Grow, Wall St. Titans See Shares Fall
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs were thought to be in a separate class from weaker banks like Bear Stearns.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs were thought to be in a separate class from weaker banks like Bear Stearns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, the two last titans left standing on Wall Street, are no longer immune.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Eric Dash

articles.headline: A New Role for the Fed: Investor of Last Resort
articles.snippet: The mighty Federal Reserve is being stretched to its limits, both in the range of problems it is being asked to fix and in its financial firepower.
articles.abstract: The mighty Federal Reserve is being stretched to its limits, both in the range of problems it is being asked to fix and in its financial firepower.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The mighty Federal Reserve is being stretched to its limits, both in the range of problems it is being asked to fix and in its financial firepower.

articles.headline: Investors, Hungry for Hope, Send Dow Up 410
articles.snippet: The Dow industrials closed up more than 400 points, but there was little relief from the paralysis that has gripped the credit markets.
articles.abstract: The Dow industrials closed up more than 400 points, but there was little relief from the paralysis that has gripped the credit markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: A seesaw day on Wall Street ended with a rush of euphoria Thursday as investors raced back into beaten-down banking shares, heartened by signs that the government is taking more drastic steps to tamp down problems plaguing the financial markets.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Pain Spreads as Credit Vise Grows Tighter
articles.snippet: Lenders have become even less willing to part with their money, further crimping budgets and family spending.
articles.abstract: Lenders have become even less willing to part with their money, further crimping budgets and family spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest outgrowth of the housing crisis, the breakdown on Wall Street, threatens to gradually corrode economic activity on Main Street, mainly by disabling the credit on which so many everyday transactions depend  but also by frightening people.
